text: something hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's yes
music nerd and it's time for a review of
new Colin Stetson album new history
warfare vol 3
Colin Stetson is a Canadian saxophone
player and he has been quite the buzz
over the past few years in jazz and
experimental music circles but he has
sort of an indie music appeal as well of
course his last full-length album was
also recorded at the infamous
hotel to tango which has been home to
many a great Canadian artists such as
silver Mount Zion Orchestra and Godspeed
you black Emperor on top of that Colin
is actually toured a little bit with God
speed too and while all of these
connections have brought Colin a lot of
visibility nothing is quite as
attention-grabbing as this man's
performances his live performances and
just his musical style in general when
it comes to playing the saxophone really
no matter what the size this man is a
machine and the man's albums in this new
history warfare music series basically
consists of these one take saxophone
pieces that flutter and howl endlessly
thanks to Colin's continuous breathing
techniques making us a never really
needs to stop playing
not only are Colin's technical abilities
really impressive but to take it even
further his music has been recorded in
some really interesting ways too with
some very strange mic placements that
not only pick up his breathing the
saxophone as well the notes that it's
making and the sounds of the valves on
the saxophones opening and closing
creating kind of a rhythmic background
for the melodic side of these pieces
that Colin is writing these have
basically been the main characteristics
of this new history warfare series and
from what I understand this is going to
be the last installment of it and I
wouldn't say the Colin is ducking out
prematurely or anything like that he
does create music on this album that
does have a sense of finality here there
are a lot of tracks on this album that
to me feel like very sentimental feel
like a hug goodbye Colin takes a lot of
the very obtuse and polarizing saxophone
experiments that he indulged in on his
previous two album
and tries to interpret and express them
in a way that feels beautiful Colin
creates moments on the south and they
feel like a new day some kind of
ascension like I'm listening to an
emotional wake-up call just some
reminder that my heart is beating and
that my lungs are pushing out air it's
time to just stop walking through life
as a stone-faced drone and just feel
something there's just something about
the way that the Stetson he blends very
simple with very complicated ideas in
his solo sax pieces from his endlessly
evolving saxophone arpeggios and runs up
and down a spectrum of pitches and how
he has these howls coming out from his
throat in the background sort of like
this very eerie
crying voice in the distance that is
muffled by the sax Reed jammed in his
mouth and also on this album
singer/songwriter Justin Vernon aka Bone
Iver comes along and contributes vocals
on a number of tracks here helping to
enhance that sentimental vibe that Colin
was going for on a lot of these tracks
however there are moments where I feel
like Justin's version of sentimental and
Colin's version of sentimental might not
necessarily I guess mesh like the
opening track on this LP and in truth
where Justin is singing in his trademark
falsetto multi-tracked soaring over
Colin's fluttering saxophone lines and
to me it just kind of feels like
Justin's voice is overtaking what
Colin's doing as opposed to sort of
complementing it but Justin doesn't
always sort of stay in his comfort zone
on this album there is the song brew
where Colin is playing especially fast
on the track just plaquing clacking his
valves he's breathing as hard as hell
making his sax just blare out furiously
and toward the back end of the song
Justin Vernon actually comes through and
contributes what sounds like death metal
style growls on the song this album
feels like a metal nightmare
the only other track that featured
Justin's voice that really sort of
impressed me was the cover of what are
they doing in heaven today originally a
Washington Phillips song a gospel tune
where we hear Justin's singing in sort
of a normal range of voice which is
actually very soulful very emot--
it actually complements the track really
well and it makes me feel as if well
maybe a normally some voice would have
suffice not just a falsetto on some of
the other tracks as well of course there
is also the 15 minute monolith of a
title track that is on this album that I
am pretty in love with the beginning of
this track has a lot of fluttering sax
lines too but the way that they're
played and the phrasing that they're
running up and down it feels very pretty
in a way but the back end of the song as
the track evolves it gets really heavy
really intense the track feels like I'm
listening to just mammoth calls like
extinct tundra mammoths that are 50 feet
tall and made of gears and pulleys
they're like mecha mammoths and they're
just leaving giant freaking footprints
in snow dunes and sheets of ice there
are a lot of highlights on this LP for
sure no question no doubt but for me
personally the downsides that this LP
offers some of the ideas are say me say
me across the album especially if you
were a huge fan of Colin's previous to
LPS as well though yes there was a
little bit more tenderness musically on
this album it doesn't really feel like
Colin is pushing his technical ability
that far on this album at least to my
ears
which if you're head over heels for
Colin might not necessarily be a deal
breaker but for me personally I wasn't
really in love with every single vocal
contribution that Bon Iver brought to
the table I was much more enamored with
what Shara Worden and Laurie Anderson
did on his last full length LP
I'm pretty much feeling a light to
decent 7 on the cell P if you've given
it a listen what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's about it
Anthony Fantana Colin Stetson forever
you
